            <choice>
              <sic>disctreion</sic>
              <corr>discretion</corr>
            </choice>
           requireth, and that soberly then...."</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">Let not Lawson that fox, be 
            <choice>
              <sic>acqainted</sic>
              <corr>acquainted</corr>
            </choice> with my letters...."</quote></l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">So 
            <choice>
              <sic>Lthe</sic>
              <corr>the</corr>
            </choice> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-duno" key="Norfolk, Duchess of">Duchess of Norfolk</rs>, mother to the poet Earl</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-easu" key="Surrey, Earl of">Surrey</rs> writes:</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><!-- find way to render gap --> </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"> </l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Fear of God, fear of man, hate, agony, passion, surround</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">them with the walls of a dungeon. There is no gaiety,</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">
            <choice>
              <sic>nu</sic>
              <corr>no</corr>
            </choice> freedom no 
            <choice>
              <sic>familairity</sic> <!-- that's a good typo -->
              <corr>familiarity</corr>
            </choice> in the world the live in. Only in</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">extremity, of hate, of fear, do urges them to pick up the pen</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The sound of the bible is in their ears, 
            <choice>
              <sic>Itis</sic>
              <corr>it is</corr>
            </choice> a garment only</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to be worn when the mind is in the right attitude. And the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">garment may of course conceal a Lady Ann who is merry and</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">gay; it may conceal a Duchess who is 
            <choice>
              <sic>snesitove</sic>
              <corr>sensitive</corr>
            </choice>, amorous</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and sensual; we cannot tell. Anybody  may live on the other</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">side of that wall of formal language. Using the prose of</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the Bible when they write prose the Elizabethans are unknown</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to us. They can say nothing simple, subtle, or little.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Bright contrasted colours meet on 
            <choice>
              <sic>ther</sic>
              <corr>their</corr>
            </choice> faces; carnation</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">and snow; ebony and gold. In their portraits, the young mens</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">bodies are sewn into padded doublets; school boys faces</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">are raised above 
            <choice>
              <sic>strached</sic>
              <corr>starched</corr>
            </choice> ruffs; and young women serve only</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to 
            <choice>
              <sic>supp rt</sic>
              <corr>support</corr>
            </choice> heavy 
            <choice>
              <sic> uilted</sic>
              <corr>quilted</corr>
            </choice> dresses stuck about with</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">huge xxxx pearls.</l>
